context: T. Gilmartin, (Professor of History, Maynooth, 1890), writes in Church History, Vol. 1, Ch XVII: On the death of Alexander, <a4_0><b11_0>five months<b11_0/><a4_0/> after the termination of the Council of Nice, Athanasius was unanimously elected to fill the vacant see. <a2_0>He was most <a5_0><b10_0>unwilling<b10_0/><a5_0/> to accept<a2_0/> the dignity, for he clearly foresaw the difficulties in which it would involve him. The clergy and <a3_0>people were determined to have him<a3_0/> as their bishop, Patriarch of Alexandria, and refused to accept any excuses. He at length consented to accept a responsibility that he sought in vain to escape, and was consecrated <a6_0>in <a0_0><b8_0>326<b8_0/><a6_0/><a0_0/>, when he was <a1_0>about <a7_0><b9_0>thirty<b9_0/> years of age<a1_0/>.
